choices.text: Incision and drainage followed by pressure dressing
Immediate referral for plastic surgery consultation

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen left ear following a physical altercation. On examination, the left auricle is markedly swollen and deformed with a fluctuant, non-erythematous area occupying most of the antihelical fold. There is no laceration or discharge, and the patient denies any hearing loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and Drainage Followed by Pressure Dressing

 

The given case describes a 22-year-old male with a swollen, fluctuant auricle following trauma, which is characteristic of an auricular hematoma.

 

  • Auricular hematoma occurs due to blunt trauma leading to blood accumulation between the perichondrium and auricular cartilage.
  • The best management is incision and drainage (I&D) followed by a pressure dressing to:
    • Evacuate the hematoma and prevent re-accumulation.
    • Maintain blood supply to the cartilage and prevent necrosis.
    • Minimize the risk of "cauliflower ear" deformity (fibrotic, deformed auricle due to chronic hematoma).

 

Procedure:

 

  1. Local anesthesia is administered.
  2. Small incision or needle aspiration to drain the hematoma.
  3. Pressure dressing is applied to prevent hematoma reformation.
  4. Antibiotics (to prevent perichondritis) may be prescribed in some cases.
  5. Follow-up is necessary to check for recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cold Compress and Analgesics: Incorrect because symptomatic treatment alone does not evacuate the hematoma. Persistent blood accumulation can cause cartilage necrosis and fibrosis, leading to a cauliflower ear deformity.

 

Option C. Oral Antibiotics and Outpatient Follow-up: Incorrect because auricular hematoma is not primarily an infection but a traumatic blood collection. Oral antibiotics do not treat the underlying hematoma, though they may be used to prevent secondary perichondritis.

 

Option D. Immediate Referral for Plastic Surgery Consultation: Incorrect because plastic surgery is not the first-line intervention for an uncomplicated auricular hematoma. Most cases are managed in the emergency or ENT department with incision, drainage, and dressing. Plastic surgery is considered only in cases of failed initial treatment or severe deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Auricular hematomas should be managed promptly with incision and drainage followed by a pressure dressing to prevent cartilage necrosis and permanent deformity (cauliflower ear). 
  • Cold compresses, antibiotics, or plastic surgery consultation alone are not sufficient initial treatments.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

choices.text: Surgical Excision of the Sinus Tract

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a small pit near her right ear, which has been present since birth. On examination, a small opening is noted anterior to the ascending limb of the helix of the right ear. There is no redness, swelling, or drainage at the time of the visit. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Observation and Hygiene Education

 

The clinical presentation is consistent with a preauricular sinus, a congenital anomaly resulting from an incomplete fusion of the first and second branchial arches.

 

  • Preauricular sinuses are typically asymptomatic and do not require surgical intervention unless they become infected or recurrently symptomatic.
  • Best initial management: 
    • Observation for signs of infection (redness, swelling, or discharge).
    • Hygiene education: Patients should be advised to keep the area clean to reduce the risk of infection.
    • Medical attention should be sought if signs of infection appear.

 

Development of Preauricular Sinus:

 

  • The external ear develops from six hillocks of His, derived from the first and second pharyngeal arches.
  • Defective fusion between the first and second arch leads to preauricular sinus formation, usually located above the tragus or at the root of the helix.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgical Excision of the Sinus Tract: Incorrect, because surgical excision is reserved for recurrent or infected cases. Performing surgery on an asymptomatic patient is unnecessary and may lead to complications such as scarring or recurrence if not completely removed.

 

Option B. Topical Antibiotic Ointment Application: Incorrect, because there is no active infection or drainage, making antibiotics unnecessary. Topical antibiotics are used only when there is localized infection, such as mild erythema or purulent discharge.

 

Option C. Systemic Antibiotics: Incorrect, because systemic antibiotics are indicated only in cases of acute infection with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, cellulitis). In an asymptomatic preauricular sinus, antibiotics offer no benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A preauricular sinus is a congenital defect resulting from incomplete fusion of the first and second pharyngeal arches. 
  • Asymptomatic cases require only observation and hygiene education. Surgical excision and antibiotics are reserved for infected or recurrently symptomatic cases.

 

Ref. P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.

choices.text: Arnold's Nerve (a branch of the Vagus Nerve)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a laceration on the upper part of his left ear following a minor car accident. He reports numbness in the area surrounding the laceration. On examination, the laceration involves the helix but does not extend to the external auditory canal. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Greater Auricular Nerve

 

  • The Greater Auricular Nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (C2, C3) and provides sensory innervation to most of the auricle (pinna) and the skin behind the ear.
  • Key anatomical significance:
    • It emerges from the cervical plexus and ascends over the sternocleidomastoid muscle to innervate the lower two-thirds of the auricle, including the helix, antihelix, and lobule.
    • Injury to this nerve, such as from a laceration to the helix, can result in numbness of the affected area.
  • Why is it the most likely affected nerve?
    • The helix is primarily innervated by the Greater Auricular Nerve.
    • The numbness around the laceration is explained by injury to the sensory supply of this nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesser Occipital Nerve: Incorrect, because the lesser occipital nerve (C2) innervates the skin over the mastoid process, posterior scalp, and upper neck. It does not provide primary sensation to the helix, making it less likely to be involved in this injury.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal Nerve: Incorrect, because the auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).

 

  • It supplies sensation to the anterosuperior portion of the external ear, external auditory meatus, and part of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).
  • Also supplies anterior half of outer surface of tympanic membrane
  • The posterior helix is not innervated by this nerve.

 

Option D. Arnold's Nerve (Auricular Branch of the Vagus Nerve): Incorrect, because Arnold’s nerve provides sensation to the external auditory canal posterior wall and concha.

 

  • Also supplies posterior half of outer surface of tympanic membrane
  • It does not supply the helix, making it unlikely to be affected in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Greater Auricular Nerve (C2, C3) is the primary sensory nerve for most of the external ear, including the helix and lobule.
  • Injury to this nerve during trauma can cause numbness in these regions.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve, lesser occipital nerve, and Arnold’s nerve provide sensation to other parts of the ear but do not primarily supply the helix.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 4.

choices.text: Start intravenous ciprofloxacin and obtain imaging
Prescribe oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and schedule follow-up
Perform immediate surgical debridement of the external auditory canal
Start topical antibiotic ear drops and oral corticosteroids

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with severe right ear pain and persistent otorrhea for the past two weeks. He reports that the pain is worse at night and does not improve with over-the-counter analgesics. Examination reveals tenderness over the external auditory canal (EAC), granulation tissue at the cartilaginous-bony junction, and cranial nerve VII weakness (right-sided facial palsy). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start Intravenous Ciprofloxacin and Obtain Imaging

 

This patient’s severe otalgia, persistent otorrhea, granulation tissue at the cartilaginous-bony junction of the external auditory canal (EAC), and facial nerve involvement are highly suggestive of malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa (MOE).

 

 

Key Features of Malignant (Necrotizing) Otitis Externa:

  • Occurs in elderly diabetic or immunocompromised patients.

  • Severe otalgia, often worse at night.

  • Persistent otorrhea and granulation tissue in the EAC (hallmark finding).

  • Facial nerve involvement (CN VII paralysis) due to infection spread to the skull base.

  • Risk of multiple cranial nerve palsies if infection spreads to the jugular foramen.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical suspicion is key in an elderly diabetic with severe otalgia and granulation tissue.

  • Imaging: 

    • Gallium-67 scan: Best for diagnosing and monitoring disease progression.

    • Technetium-99 bone scan: Shows bone involvement but remains positive for a long time.

    • CT scan: May show bony destruction but is less sensitive than Gallium-67.

 

Management:

  1. Control of Diabetes: Essential for treatment success.

  2. IV Ciprofloxacin (or an alternative anti-Pseudomonal regimen): 

    • Ciprofloxacin 750 mg PO BID or IV 400 mg q8h (Quinolones are preferred due to good bone penetration).

    • Alternative: Ceftazidime + Aminoglycoside (e.g., Gentamicin).

    • Piperacillin

  3. Debridement of necrotic tissue/granulation if needed. (If not responding to conservative management or If patient presented with complications).

  4. Prolonged antibiotic course (6–8 weeks).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prescribe Oral Amoxicillin-Clavulanate and Schedule Follow-up.

  • Incorrect, because MOE is a life-threatening condition that requires aggressive IV antibiotics.

  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate is not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the most common causative organism.

 

Option C. Perform Immediate Surgical Debridement of the External Auditory Canal:

  • Incorrect, because radical surgery is no longer first-line treatment.

  • Prolonged IV antibiotic therapy is preferred over extensive surgical debridement.

 

Option D. Start Topical Antibiotic Ear Drops and Oral Corticosteroids:

  • Incorrect, because MOE requires systemic antibiotics.

  • Corticosteroids are contraindicated in uncontrolled infections as they suppress immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is a life-threatening Pseudomonas infection seen in elderly diabetics, characterized by severe otalgia, persistent otorrhea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and possible cranial nerve palsies. Management includes IV ciprofloxacin, diabetes control, and prolonged antibiotic therapy (6–8 weeks).

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a one-week history of itching and fullness in her right ear. She reports no pain but mentions a slight hearing reduction. She has a history of swimming regularly. On examination, the external auditory canal is erythematous and has black-headed filamentous debris. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Which microorganism is most commonly responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus Niger

 

The clinical presentation suggests otomycosis, a fungal infection of the external auditory canal. Aspergillus niger is the most common cause of otomycosis, particularly in individuals with frequent water exposure (swimming).

 

 

  • Key features of otomycosis:

    • Itching (most common symptom).

    • Ear fullness or blocked sensation.

    • Mild hearing loss (due to fungal debris).

    • Black-headed filamentous fungal debris (suggestive of Aspergillus niger infection).

    • Minimal pain and no significant purulent discharge (unlike bacterial otitis externa).

  • Risk factors:

    • Frequent swimming (creates a moist environment).

    • Use of topical antibiotics or steroids (alters ear flora).

    • Immunocompromised states (e.g., diabetes, HIV).

  • Management:

    • Aural toilet (removal of fungal debris).

    • Topical antifungal therapy (clotrimazole, ketoconazole, or nystatin ear drops).

    • Avoidance of moisture in the external auditory canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa:

  • Incorrect, because Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes Malignant otitis externa, not otomycosis.

  • Bacterial otitis externa presents with more pain and purulent discharge, not black fungal debris.

 

Option C. Candida Albicans:

  • Incorrect, because Candida albicans can cause otomycosis but is less common than Aspergillus species.

  • Candida infections usually appear as white, curd-like debris rather than black-headed fungal growth.

  • More common in immunocompromised patients or those with chronic antibiotic use.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus Aureus:

  • Incorrect, because Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterial pathogen and does not cause otomycosis.

  • It is more commonly associated with localized infections like furuncles or bacterial otitis externa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus niger is the most common cause of otomycosis, a fungal infection of the external auditory canal. It presents with itching, ear fullness, and black-headed filamentous fungal debris, particularly in individuals with frequent swimming exposure. Management includes aural toilet and topical antifungal therapy.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with acute onset of right-sided facial paralysis, severe ear pain, and a vesicular rash in his right ear. He also reports some hearing loss and vertigo on the same side. His past medical history is significant for chickenpox in childhood. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) is caused by the reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) in the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (CN VII).

 

 

Key Features of Ramsay Hunt Syndrome:

 

Triad of symptoms:

  1. Ipsilateral facial paralysis (similar to Bell’s palsy).

  2. Severe otalgia (ear pain).

  3. Vesicular rash in the external ear, ear canal, or oral mucosa.

Additional symptoms:

  • Hearing loss and vertigo (due to involvement of the vestibulocochlear nerve - CN VIII).

  • Tinnitus and altered taste sensation (chorda tympani involvement).

  • Dry eyes and mouth (due to autonomic involvement of CN VII).

Management:

  • Oral Acyclovir or Valacyclovir (antiviral therapy).

  • Systemic corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone to reduce inflammation and nerve damage).

  • Analgesics for pain control.

  • Artificial tears and eye protection (to prevent corneal damage from incomplete eye closure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bell’s Palsy:

  • Incorrect, because Bell’s palsy is an isolated facial nerve palsy without other cranial nerve involvement.

  • It does not cause vesicular rash, ear pain, or hearing loss, which are seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

 

Option B. Acute Otitis Media (AOM):

  • Incorrect, because AOM can cause ear pain but does not cause facial paralysis or vesicular rash.

  • AOM is typically associated with fever, bulging tympanic membrane, and conductive hearing loss, which are absent in this case.

 

 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma):

  • Incorrect, because acoustic neuromas cause progressive, not acute, hearing loss.

  • They do not cause facial paralysis or vesicular rash.

  • Symptoms are gradual and include hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus, rather than sudden onset.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) is caused by reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and a vesicular rash in the ear or oral mucosa. It can also involve the vestibulocochlear nerve, causing hearing loss and vertigo. Early treatment with antivirals and corticosteroids improves outcomes.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

choices.text: Furuncle of the external auditory canal

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic with a two-day history of severe pain in her right ear. She reports a sensation of fullness and decreased hearing on the affected side. On examination, the External Auditory Canal (EAC) is noted to be swollen with a visible red, tender nodule near the outer third. There is no discharge or tympanic membrane perforation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Furuncle of the External Auditory Canal

 

A furuncle in the external auditory canal is a localized infection and inflammation of a hair follicle and surrounding tissue, most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents as a painful, red, swollen nodule in the outer cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal (EAC), which is consistent with this patient's symptoms. A positive tragal sign (pain when pressing the tragus or moving the pinna) is typical in such cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Otitis Externa: Incorrect because acute otitis externa often presents with diffuse swelling of the EAC, pain, and sometimes discharge, but the presence of a localized, tender nodule indicates a more specific condition like a furuncle.

 

 

Option B. Eustachian Tube Dysfunction: Incorrect because Eustachian tube dysfunction typically presents with fullness, ear popping, and fluctuating hearing loss but does not cause localized swelling or a tender nodule in the EAC.

 

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: Incorrect because a cholesteatoma is a growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear or mastoid process. It usually presents with painless otorrhea and hearing loss, but would not typically present as a tender nodule in the EAC.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A furuncle of the external auditory canal is a localized infection of a hair follicle, presenting as a painful, red, swollen nodule in the canal, often associated with severe pain and a sensation of fullness. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus, and the tragal sign is positive. 

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 51-52.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic patient presents with severe ear pain, otorrhea, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal. The patient is diagnosed with malignant otitis externa. Which organism is most commonly responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas Aeruginosa is the most common causative organism of malignant otitis externa, especially in diabetic patients or individuals with compromised immune systems. Malignant otitis externa is a severe, invasive infection that begins in the external auditory canal and can progress to involve the skull base, making it a potentially life-threatening condition. It is characterized by severe ear pain, otorrhea, and the presence of granulation tissue in the external auditory canal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus Aureus: Incorrect because while Staphylococcus Aureus is a common cause of skin and soft tissue infections, it is not the most frequent cause of malignant otitis externa compared to Pseudomonas Aeruginosa.

 

Option C. Aspergillus Niger: Incorrect because Aspergillus Niger is more commonly associated with fungal otitis externa, which is less aggressive and typically presents differently from malignant otitis externa.

 

 

Option D. Streptococcus Pneumoniae: Incorrect because Streptococcus Pneumoniae is a common cause of otitis media (middle ear infection) but is not typically involved in malignant otitis externa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomonas Aeruginosa is the most common organism responsible for malignant otitis externa, especially in diabetic patients and those with compromised immune systems. Early identification and treatment are critical to prevent complications such as skull base involvement.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

choices.text: Squamous epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane
Mucous membrane, Fibrous layer, Squamous epithelium
Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane, Squamous epithelium
Squamous epithelium, Mucous membrane, Fibrous layer

questions.text: A medical student is studying the anatomy of the ear and learns about the layers of the tympanic membrane (TM). Which of the following correctly lists the layers of the TM from outermost to innermost?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous Epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane

 

Option A. 

 

The Tympanic membrane is composed of three layers.

 

  • The outermost layer is Squamous Epithelium (Ectodermal derivative), which is continuous with the skin of the external auditory canal.
  • The middle layer is a Fibrous layer (Mesodermal derivative), providing the TM with its strength and elasticity.
  • The innermost layer is a mucous membrane (Endodermal derivative), continuous with the lining of the middle ear cavity.

 

This arrangement (A) is the correct description of the layers of the TM. Also note that the 3 layers of tympanic membrane are developed from 3 embryonic germ layers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This option incorrectly lists the layers in reverse order.

 

Option C. This option incorrectly orders the layers, placing the fibrous layer first.

 

Option D. This option also incorrectly lists the stratified squamous epithelium and mucous membrane, reversing their positions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical layering of the tympanic membrane consists of an outer stratified squamous epithelial layer, a middle fibrous layer, and an inner mucous membrane layer. This knowledge is important for understanding various ear pathologies and their treatments.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg3

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with pain localized to his left ear. There is no history of trauma or infection. An ENT specialist notes that the pain could be due to neuralgia involving a specific nerve plexus within the middle ear. Which nerve plexus is most likely involved in mediating this patient's ear pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tympanic Plexus

 

Option A. 

 

The tympanic plexus is a network of nerves found on the medial wall of the middle ear. It is formed by the tympanic branch (Jacobson’s nerve) of the Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX) and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the middle ear, mastoid air cells, and part of the tympanic membrane. Neuralgia involving this plexus can manifest as ear pain without any apparent external or middle ear pathology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The carotid plexus is a network of sympathetic nerves surrounding the carotid artery and is not primarily involved in sensory innervation of the ear.

 

Option C. The cervical plexus provides sensory and motor innervation to structures in the neck, but it does not directly innervate the middle ear or tympanic membrane to a significant extent.

 

Option D. The pharyngeal plexus is primarily involved in innervating the pharynx and does not play a major role in sensory innervation of the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tympanic plexus, primarily formed by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, provides sensory innervation to the middle ear and can be involved in ear pain syndromes such as neuralgia.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg8

questions.text: A medical student is learning about the innervation of the tympanic membrane. Which nerve is responsible for the sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Option A: 

 

The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is itself a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), is responsible for the sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane. This innervation is important for the sensation of pain, temperature, and touch in this region of the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) does provide some innervation to the tympanic membrane, particularly to the outer posterior half surface via the auricular branch (also known as Arnold's nerve), but it is not primarily responsible for the sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option C: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) innervates a portion of the tympanic membrane, particularly the inner surface, via its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). However, it is not the main nerve supplying the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is mainly responsible for motor innervation in the facial region and does not provide sensory innervation to the tympanic membrane. Via nervus intermedius (sensory fibres of facial nerve), it supplies posterior wall of external auditory canal. This nerve is responsible for hitselberger sign in acoustic neuroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane is provided by the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg4

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with acute onset of severe ear pain and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals multiple blisters on the tympanic membrane. This presentation is most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Myringitis bullosa

 

Option A: 

 

Myringitis Bullosa is characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane and can be associated with severe ear pain and temporary hearing loss. It is often seen in conjunction with viral upper respiratory tract infections or as a manifestation of viral infections such as influenza. Mycoplasma pneumonia is supposed to be the causative. Ofcourse, bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae, Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus are also known causatives. The blebs are formed in between the middle and outer layers of tympanic membrane. Most commonly, it is a self-limiting disease. Antibiotics and steroids can be suggested, if required.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Acute otitis media typically presents with ear pain, hearing loss, and a red, bulging tympanic membrane, but without the vesicles or blisters that are characteristic of myringitis bullosa.

 

 

Option C: Cholesteatoma is a chronic condition characterized by the accumulation of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear, which can lead to hearing loss and discharge. It does not present with blisters on the tympanic membrane.

 

 

Option D: Traumatic tympanic membrane perforation is typically associated with sudden sharp ear pain followed by relief and possibly hearing loss, but it is not characterized by the presence of blisters on the tympanic membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringitis bullosa is a condition characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane, often associated with severe ear pain and temporary hearing loss, and commonly seen in the context of viral infections.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg55

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of muffled hearing in her right ear. She has a history of recurrent otitis media in childhood but no recent infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a retracted right tympanic membrane, with the fibrous annulus becoming more prominent. The cone of light is missing, and the lateral process of the malleus is prominent due to the medialized handle of the malleus. There is no contact with the ossicles or any signs of ossicular erosion. According to Sade's classification, which stage of pars tensa retraction does this patient's condition correspond to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grade I

 

Option A:

 

Grade I of pars tensa retraction is characterized by a slight retraction of the pars tensa, where the fibrous annulus becomes more prominent, and the cone of light is missing. The lateral process of the malleus is prominent due to the unopposed medial pull of the tensor tympani muscle, leading to a medialized handle of the malleus. This description matches the patient's presentation, where there is no contact with the ossicles or any signs of ossicular erosion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade II pars tensa retraction involves further retraction where the pars tensa retracts and touches the long process of the incus. Visible structures may include the incudostapedial joint, stapedius tendon, round window, and part of the horizontal facial nerve. The lateral process of the malleus becomes more prominent. This stage is more advanced than what is described for the patient.

 

 

Option C. Grade III retraction of the pars tensa is more severe, where the pars tensa medializes more and adheres to the promontory, referred to as an atelectatic tympanic membrane. Some air pockets may still be present in the middle ear, indicating a more advanced state than the patient's condition.

 

 

Option D. Grade IV retraction involves further retraction leading to complete adhesion of the tympanic membrane to the promontory with no middle ear air, known as adhesive otitis media. In this stage, there may be ossicular necrosis, such as necrosis of the lenticular process of the incus, and the tympanic membrane is adhered to the promontory, representing a very advanced stage of retraction not seen in the patient's description.

 

 

The patient's symptoms and otoscopic findings correspond to Grade I retraction according to Sade's classification, indicating a slight retraction of the pars tensa without involvement or erosion of the ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade I pars tensa retraction according to Sade's classification, characterized by slight retraction, a more prominent fibrous annulus, absence of the cone of light, and a prominent lateral process of the malleus due to the medialized handle of the malleus, with no contact with the ossicles or signs of ossicular erosion.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents to you with intellectual disability and hearing loss and you notice the following external ear anomaly. What could be the anomaly in this case be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preauricular Tag

 

  • The external ear anomaly visible in the image is a preauricular tag (preauricular appendage), which is a congenital external ear anomaly. It appears as a skin-covered piece of cartilage located anywhere between the tragus and the angle of the mouth. 
  • These tags arise due to abnormal development of the first and second branchial arches during embryogenesis.
  • Preauricular tags are commonly associated with syndromes such as Goldenhar syndrome, which presents with:
  • Facial asymmetry
  • Hearing loss
  • Preauricular skin tags

 

Other Options:


Option A. Ganglion: A ganglion is a fluid-filled cystic swelling that typically arises from tendons or joint capsules rather than the external ear.

 

  • It is not congenital and is not associated with hearing loss or intellectual disability.

 

 

Option B. Preauricular Sinus: A preauricular sinus is a small pit or opening near the anterior margin of the ear, which may lead to a subcutaneous tract.

 

  • Unlike a preauricular tag, it does not appear as a raised cartilage-like mass.
  • It is associated with recurrent infections rather than syndromic conditions.

 

 

Option D. Neurodermatitis: Neurodermatitis (lichen simplex chronicus) is a chronic skin condition caused by repeated scratching, leading to thickened, lichenified plaques. It is not congenital and does not appear as an isolated external ear anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preauricular tags are congenital external ear anomalies that may be isolated or syndromic (e.g., Goldenhar syndrome). Any newborn with external ear anomalies should undergo hearing screening and evaluation for associated syndromes, as these anomalies may indicate underlying structural or genetic conditions affecting craniofacial development.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 51

choices.text: Ear cartilage has reached full adult size.
Prevention of psychological distress from peer teasing.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for a pinnaplasty due to prominent ears. The parents inquire about the rationale for choosing this age for the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate reason for performing pinnaplasty at this age?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the Above

 

  • Pinnaplasty (also called Otoplasty) is a surgical procedure performed to correct prominent ears for both functional and cosmetic reasons. The ideal age for the surgery is around 6 years, due to the following key factors:

 

Option A. Ear cartilage has reached near adult size: By age 6, the external ear has grown to about 85–90% of its adult size. Performing the surgery at this stage ensures that reshaping is accurate and stable with minimal future changes.

 

Option B. Chondral cartilage is mature enough for reshaping: At this age, the cartilage is flexible yet strong, making it easier to reshape and maintain the new position postoperatively. If done earlier, the cartilage may be too soft and prone to deformation, while delaying the procedure might reduce cartilage malleability.

 

Option C. Prevention of psychological distress from peer teasing: Children often start school around this age, and prominent ears can lead to teasing, bullying, and psychological distress.  Early correction helps improve self-esteem and confidence before negative social experiences occur.

 

  • Because all these factors contribute to the decision for surgery, option D (All of the Above) is the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pinnaplasty (Otoplasty) is ideally performed at around 6 years of age because:
    • The external ear has reached near-adult size (~85–90%).
    • The cartilage is mature yet flexible enough for reshaping.
    • Psychological distress from peer teasing can be prevented.
      A combination of these factors makes 6 years the optimal time for the procedure.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a three-day history of pain and swelling in his right ear. He has no significant past medical history but recalls scratching his ear with a toothpick a few days ago. On examination, the right pinna is erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch, especially around the cartilage. There is no discharge or fluctuance, and the auditory canal appears normal. The tympanic membrane is intact and mobile. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral Antibiotics and Analgesics

 

  • The clinical presentation of erythema, swelling, and tenderness localized to the auricular cartilage without fluctuance suggests perichondritis—a bacterial infection of the auricular cartilage commonly caused by trauma (e.g., scratching with a toothpick).
  • Most Common Pathogen: Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Other Possible Pathogens: Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus species
  • Management: 
  • Oral antibiotics (fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin) to cover Pseudomonas and other bacterial causes.
  • Analgesics to relieve inflammation-related pain.
  • If abscess formation occurs, incision and drainage may be needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Antivirals and Analgesics: Incorrect, because viral infections (e.g., herpes zoster oticus/Ramsay Hunt syndrome) do not cause isolated cartilage inflammation. Herpes zoster oticus would present with vesicular rash, facial nerve palsy, and otalgia, which are absent in this case.

 

Option C. Incision and Drainage: Incorrect, because incision and drainage are only indicated if there is abscess formation. This case lacks fluctuance, meaning there is no abscess—only diffuse inflammation of the cartilage.

 

Early perichondritis is treated conservatively with antibiotics before an abscess develops. 

 

Option D. Topical Antibiotic Ear Drops: Incorrect, because topical antibiotic ear drops are only effective for otitis externa (infection of the external auditory canal), not perichondritis. Perichondritis requires systemic antibiotics as the infection is deeper and involves cartilage, not just the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular cartilage, commonly occurring after trauma and often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Early recognition and treatment with systemic antibiotics (fluoroquinolones) are crucial to prevent cartilage necrosis and auricular deformity. Incision and drainage are reserved for abscess formation, and topical antibiotics are ineffective for deep cartilage infections.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

choices.text: Directly towards the tympanic membrane
Upward towards the roof of the external auditory canal
Downward towards the floor of the external auditory canal
Towards the postero-superior wall of the external auditory canal

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic for earwax removal. He has a history of excessive cerumen accumulation and has been experiencing decreased hearing in his left ear. The nurse prepares to irrigate his ear. In which direction should the syringe be aimed during irrigation to safely and effectively remove the earwax?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Towards the postero-superior wall of the external auditory canal

 

Option D. The most effective and safest direction for ear syringing is towards the postero-superior wall of the external auditory canal. This direction allows for the stream of water to get behind the wax, facilitating its removal, and minimizes the risk of injury to the tympanic membrane.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Directing the syringe directly towards the tympanic membrane is not recommended as it may increase the risk of injury to the membrane, especially if the pressure of the irrigation is high.

 

Option B. Aiming the syringe upward towards the roof of the external auditory canal is not the most effective direction for removing earwax. This position does not facilitate the natural exit pathway of the earwax from the canal.

 

Option C. Aiming downward towards the floor of the external auditory canal is also not effective for earwax removal and can cause pooling of water in the canal, increasing the risk of infection or irritation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During ear irrigation for earwax removal, the syringe should be aimed towards the postero-superior wall of the external auditory canal to effectively dislodge the wax and minimize the risk of injury to the tympanic membrane.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 53

choices.text: Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1
Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with facial weakness on the right side, vesicular lesions in the right external auditory canal, and severe ear pain. The physician suspects Ramsay Hunt Syndrome. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Varicella-Zoster Virus

 

Option C: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome, also known as Herpes Zoster Oticus, is caused by the reactivation of the Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) in the Geniculate Ganglion. It presents with a triad of symptoms including ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicular eruptions in the ear canal or on the auricle. VZV is the same virus that causes chickenpox in children and shingles in adults.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) typically causes oral herpes, which can include cold sores or fever blisters, but it is not the virus responsible for Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Option B: Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) is generally associated with genital herpes and is not the causative agent of Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Option D: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with warts and certain cancers but is not associated with Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, presenting with facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicular eruptions in the ear canal or on the auricle.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 52

choices.text: Stimulation of the Vagus Nerve
Allergic reaction to the Cerumeno lytic Agent
Reflex from the Glosso-pharyngeal Nerve
Irritation of the Tympanic Membrane

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes ear wax removal. During the procedure, he experiences a sudden coughing fit. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stimulation of the Vagus Nerve

 

Option A. The Vagus Nerve (Arnold's Nerve) provides sensory innervations to a part of the external auditory canal. Stimulation of this nerve during procedures like ear wax removal can trigger the auricular cough reflex, resulting in a cough.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. An allergic reaction to the cerumenolytic agent used in ear wax removal is possible, but it would more likely cause symptoms like itching, swelling, or a rash in the ear canal rather than inducing a cough reflex.

 

Option C. The glossopharyngeal nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the oropharynx and back of the tongue. While it is involved in the gag reflex, it is less likely to be stimulated during ear wax removal compared to the vagus nerve.

 

Option D. Irritation of the tympanic membrane can cause discomfort or pain but is less likely to induce a cough reflex. The tympanic membrane does not have a direct connection to the cough reflex pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stimulation of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve) in the external auditory canal during ear procedures like wax removal can trigger the auricular cough reflex, leading to coughing.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 53, 54

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic history of right ear pain, hearing loss, and occasional discharge. She denies any history of swimming or trauma to the ear. On examination, the external auditory canal (EAC) is filled with compacted keratinous material. The tympanic membrane is not visible due to the obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keratosis Obturans

 

Keratosis Obturans is characterized by the accumulation of compacted keratinous material in the EAC, leading to symptoms of pain, hearing loss, and occasional discharge. It differs from cerumen impaction in that the material is densely packed keratin rather than ear wax.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerumen Impaction typically presents with hearing loss and a sensation of fullness but is usually not associated with chronic pain or discharge. It can be easily distinguished from keratosis obturans by the nature of the material in the EAC (Wax vs. Compacted Keratin).

 

Option B. Cholesteatoma involves the accumulation of keratinized squamous epithelium in the middle ear or mastoid and can present with chronic ear discharge and hearing loss. However, it does not typically fill the EAC with keratinous material like keratosis obturans.

 

Option D. Otitis externa (swimmer's ear) typically presents with ear pain, itching, and discharge. It is usually associated with water exposure and affects the skin lining of the EAC rather than filling it with keratinous material.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis Obturans is characterized by the accumulation of compacted keratinous material in the external auditory canal, leading to symptoms like pain, hearing loss, and occasional discharge, without a history of frequent water exposure or trauma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 55

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic otitis externa presents to the clinic complaining of persistent ear discharge and hearing loss. He has a history of frequent cotton swab use for ear cleaning. Examination reveals copious purulent discharge in the external auditory canal, and the tympanic membrane is not visible. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform Aural Toilet

 

In patients with chronic otitis externa with copious discharge, the first step in management is aural toilet to remove debris and allow for better visualization and treatment.

 

  • Aural toilet methods include: 

    • Suction clearance (preferred method).

    • Irrigation with sterile normal saline (if the tympanic membrane is intact).

    • Dry mopping with sterile cotton swabs.

  • Purpose: 

    • Removes debris and pus.

    • Improves effectiveness of topical antibiotic therapy.

    • Allows better visualization of the tympanic membrane to rule out complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe Oral Antibiotics:

  • Incorrect, because oral antibiotics may be required for localized otitis externa but before starting systemic antibiotics, do aural toileting initially

  • Topical antibiotics (after aural toilet) are the first-line treatment unless there is extensive cellulitis or systemic involvement.

 

Option C. Immediate Referral for Surgical Intervention:

  • Incorrect, because surgery is not the first-line treatment for uncomplicated chronic otitis externa.

  • Surgical intervention (e.g., canaloplasty) is only needed in refractory cases or when complications like stenosis or osteomyelitis occur.

 

Option D. Initiate Topical Antifungal Therapy:

  • Incorrect, because the presence of purulent discharge suggests a bacterial, not fungal, infection.

  • Fungal otitis externa (otomycosis) is typically characterized by thick, white, or black debris with itching rather than purulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aural toilet is the essential first step in managing chronic otitis externa with significant discharge. It allows for proper examination, diagnosis, and effective delivery of topical treatments. Oral antibiotics can be given next and surgery is reserved for complicated or refractory cases.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents to the clinic with impacted cerumen. During the consultation, the resident explains about the glands in the external auditory canal (EAC) that contribute to cerumen production. Which type of glands predominantly contribute to the production of cerumen in the EAC?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apocrine Sweat Glands

 

The Apocrine Sweat Glands in the cartilaginous portion of the external auditory canal (EAC) are primarily responsible for cerumen (earwax) production.

 

 

  • Cerumen composition: 

    • Secretions from apocrine sweat glands (main contributors).

    • Secretions from sebaceous glands (minor contribution).

    • Shed keratinocytes and hair follicle debris.

  • Function of cerumen: 

    • Lubrication of the external auditory canal.

    • Protection against infections due to its antimicrobial properties.

    • Traps dust and foreign particles, preventing them from reaching the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eccrine Sweat Glands:

  • Incorrect, because eccrine glands regulate body temperature by producing watery sweat.

  • They are not found in the external auditory canal.

     

Option B. Sebaceous Glands:

  • Incorrect, because sebaceous glands contribute to cerumen by secreting sebum, but they play a secondary role compared to apocrine glands.

 

Option D. Salivary Glands:

  • Incorrect, because salivary glands are found in the oral cavity, not the external auditory canal.

  • They produce saliva, not cerumen.

     

Educational Objective:

 

Cerumen (earwax) is primarily produced by apocrine sweat glands in the external auditory canal, with a minor contribution from sebaceous glands. It plays a protective role by preventing infections, trapping foreign particles, and lubricating the ear canal.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 53.

questions.text: During an otoscopic examination, a physician prepares to examine a 30-year-old adult patient's ear. What is the appropriate direction to pull the pinna for optimal visualization of the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upward and Backward

 

For an otoscopic examination in adults, the correct maneuver is to pull the pinna upward and backward. This action straightens the external auditory canal, allowing a clearer view of the tympanic membrane and canal.

 

 

  • The external auditory canal in adults is S-shaped and has a slight upward and forward inclination.

  • Pulling the pinna upward and backward straightens the canal, facilitating visualization of the tympanic membrane.

 

Steps for Otoscopic Examination in Adults:

  1. Hold the otoscope like a pen with the dominant hand.

  2. Use the non-dominant hand to pull the pinna upward and backward.

  3. Insert the otoscope gently into the external auditory canal, avoiding excessive pressure.

  4. Adjust the angle slightly to get the best view of the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Straight Forward:

  • Incorrect, because pulling the pinna straight forward does not straighten the external auditory canal, making visualization difficult.

 

Option B. Downward and Forward:

  • Incorrect, because this technique is used for infants and young children under the age of 3, whose external auditory canal is shorter and more horizontal.

  • In adults, this technique does not provide an optimal view.

 

Option D. Upward and Forward:

  • Incorrect, because pulling the pinna upward and forward does not sufficiently align the external auditory canal, leading to suboptimal visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an otoscopic examination in adults, the pinna should be pulled upward and backward to straighten the external auditory canal, ensuring optimal visualization of the tympanic membrane. In children under 3 years, the pinna should be pulled downward and forward due to anatomical differences in the ear canal.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

choices.text: Bony protrusions along the canal wall
Granulation tissue at the floor of the canal
Slight erythema of the canal skin

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with ear pain and decreased hearing in his left ear. On clinical examination, the physician intends to thoroughly evaluate the external auditory canal (EAC). Which of the following findings would be most concerning when examining the EAC?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granulation Tissue at the Floor of the Canal

 

The presence of granulation tissue in the external auditory canal (EAC) is a concerning finding, as it suggests:

Chronic infection (e.g., malignant otitis externa).

Cholesteatoma (abnormal keratinizing epithelium growth in the middle ear).

Underlying malignancy (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma).

 

Key Features of Granulation Tissue in EAC:

  • Can appear red, friable, and vascularized.

  • Often associated with persistent ear drainage, pain, and conductive hearing loss.

  • Common in diabetics and immunocompromised individuals (suspect malignant otitis externa if present).

 

Next Steps in Management:

  • Otoscopy & Imaging (CT or MRI to evaluate bony erosion).

  • Biopsy if malignancy is suspected.

  • Culture-directed antibiotic therapy if infection is suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerumen:

  • Incorrect, because cerumen (earwax) is a normal finding in the external auditory canal.

  • It can cause conductive hearing loss if impacted, but it is not worrisome unless associated with infection or obstruction.

 

 

Option B. Bony Protrusions Along the Canal Wall:

  • Incorrect, because these are typically benign findings (e.g., exostoses or osteomas).

  • Exostoses are common in swimmers and divers due to chronic cold water exposure.

  • They rarely cause symptoms unless they obstruct the ear canal, leading to cerumen impaction or infections.

 

 

Option D: Slight Erythema of the Canal Skin

  • Incorrect, because mild erythema can be seen in irritation, otitis externa, or eczema, which are not immediately alarming.

  • Unlike granulation tissue, erythema does not indicate chronic infection or malignancy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulation tissue in the external auditory canal is a red flag that may indicate chronic infection (malignant otitis externa), cholesteatoma, or malignancy. Further evaluation with otoscopy, imaging, and biopsy is warranted in suspicious cases.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

choices.text: The lateral third, consisting of cartilage, allows for flexibility during examination.
The isthmus, the narrowest part of the EAC, can limit visualization of the tympanic membrane.
The medial two-thirds, made of bone, provide protection to deeper structures.
The junction where the bony and cartilaginous parts meet, often the site of cerumen impaction.

questions.text: A medical student is learning about ear anatomy during an otolaryngology rotation. The attending physician points out a narrow region in the external auditory canal (EAC) and explains that this area can sometimes obstruct the view of the tympanic membrane during an otoscopic examination. Which part of the EAC is being described, and what is its significance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The isthmus, the narrowest part of the EAC, can limit visualization of the tympanic membrane.

 

  • The isthmus is located around 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane and marks the narrowest part of the EAC.
  • This anatomical narrowing can indeed obstruct the direct line of sight to the tympanic membrane during otoscopic examination.
  • This is clinically significant as it explains why the pinna must be manipulated (pulled upward, backward, and laterally) to straighten the canal during ear examination.

 

The external auditory canal (EAC) is approximately 24 mm long and divided into:

  • Outer one-third (8 mm): Cartilaginous
  • Inner two-thirds (16 mm): Bony

 

 

Option A. The lateral third, consisting of cartilage, allows for flexibility during examination:

 

Partially true:

  • The lateral one-third (cartilaginous) of the canal does allow flexibility and contains ceruminous and pilosebaceous glands, producing wax.
  • However, it is not the narrowest or the point that obstructs tympanic membrane visibility.
  • Not the best answer to the specific question.

 

Option C. The medial two-thirds, made of bone, provide protection to deeper structures:

 

True but not most relevant:

  • The bony part does protect deeper structures, including the tympanic membrane and middle ear.
  • However, it is not the part that directly impairs visualization — that is the job of the isthmus.

 

Option D: The junction where the bony and cartilaginous parts meet, often the site of cerumen impaction.

 

Also true:

  • This junction (cartilaginous-bony junction) is a common site for cerumen impaction due to the narrowing and change in the epithelial lining.
  • Still, this option doesn’t directly address the visual limitation during otoscopy, which is best explained by the isthmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal and can limit tympanic membrane visualization during otoscopy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections involving both the parotid gland and the external auditory canal. Which anatomical feature is most likely facilitating the spread of infection between these two regions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fissures of Santorini

 

This question focuses on anatomical pathways that allow the spread of infection between the external auditory canal (EAC) and adjacent structures — in this case, the parotid gland.

 

  • These are natural defects or gaps in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal.
  • They serve as potential pathways for infection to spread from the EAC to the parotid gland and vice versa.
  • Clinical relevance: Recurrent infections involving both regions can be due to this anatomical communication.
  • This is particularly seen in otitis externa that may spread to the parotid area, or parotitis causing secondary EAC inflammation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube Dysfunction: 

 

  • The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, not to the EAC or parotid gland.
  • Dysfunction here may lead to otitis media, but not spread between EAC and parotid.

 

Option C: Mastoid Air Cells involvement 

 

  • Mastoid air cells are posterior to the middle ear, and infections here cause mastoiditis.
  • They do not communicate directly with the parotid gland or EAC.

 

Option D: Tympanic Membrane Perforation 

 

  • A perforated tympanic membrane connects external ear canal to the middle ear, not the parotid gland.
  • It may lead to otitis media but not parotid involvement.

 

Additional Related Anatomy Insight:

 

  • Foramen of Huschke is a bony defect in the anteroinferior part of the bony EAC, occasionally persisting into adulthood.
    It can also serve as a potential communication between EAC and the parotid, but it is less commonly patent than the Fissures of Santorini, making Santorini fissures more clinically relevant in recurrent infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fissures of Santorini in the cartilaginous external auditory canal allow infection to spread between the EAC and the parotid gland.

choices.text: The outer one-third is bony and lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands, while the inner two-thirds is cartilaginous and lacks these structures.
The entire EAC is cartilaginous and lined with skin containing hair follicles and ceruminous glands.
The outer one-third is cartilaginous and lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands, while the inner two-thirds is bony and lacks these structures.
The EAC is divided into equal bony and cartilaginous halves, both lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands.

questions.text: A medical resident is learning about the anatomy of the external auditory canal (EAC) during an otolaryngology rotation. The attending physician explains the division of the EAC and its clinical importance. Which of the following correctly describes the division of the external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The outer one-third is cartilaginous and lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands, while the inner two-thirds is bony and lacks these structures.

 

 

The external auditory canal (EAC) is anatomically divided into two distinct parts:

  • Outer one-third: Cartilaginous, lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands (responsible for producing earwax).

  • Inner two-thirds: Bony, lined with thin skin that lacks hair follicles and ceruminous glands.

 

This division is clinically significant because it helps explain the pathophysiology of certain ear conditions, such as infections or cerumen impaction, and is relevant in surgical procedures involving the ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The outer one-third is bony and the inner two-thirds is cartilaginous:

  • Incorrect, because the outer part of the EAC is cartilaginous, not bony.

 

Option B. The entire external auditory canal is cartilaginous:

  • Incorrect, because the EAC is not entirely cartilaginous; it is divided into a cartilaginous outer portion and a bony inner portion.

 

Option D. The external auditory canal is equally divided into bony and cartilaginous halves:

  • Incorrect, because the bony portion of the EAC constitutes two-thirds, not half, of the canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The external auditory canal is divided into an outer cartilaginous third, which contains hair follicles and ceruminous glands, and an inner bony two-thirds, which lacks these structures. This anatomical knowledge is crucial for understanding ear pathology and clinical management.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with acute onset of severe pain in her left ear. She denies any history of trauma or infection. On examination, she experiences intense pain when the anterior wall of the external auditory canal (EAC) is gently palpated. Which nerve is most likely responsible for the innervation of this area of the EAC?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The Auriculo-Temporal Nerve

 

The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory innervation to the anterior wall of the external auditory canal. Pain in this area, especially in the absence of trauma or infection, may suggest neuralgia involving this nerve.

 

 

Key Features of Auriculotemporal Nerve (V3):

  • Branch of the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve.

  • Provides sensory innervation to the anterior wall of the external auditory canal.

  • Involvement of this nerve can lead to localized pain or neuralgia in the anterior EAC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The Greater auricular nerve:

  • Incorrect, because the greater auricular nerve, a branch of the cervical plexus, innervates the majority of the auricle or pinna, not the anterior wall of the EAC.

 

Option C. The Vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve):

  • Incorrect, because Arnold's nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X), innervates the posterior part of the external auditory canal and may cause referred otalgia from cardiac, respiratory, or gastrointestinal conditions. It does not innervate the anterior wall.

 

Option D. The Facial nerve:

  • Incorrect, because the facial nerve (CN VII) provides motor innervation to facial muscles, but its sensory branch (nervus intermedius) provides sensory innervation to the posterior wall of the external auditory canal, along with Arnold's nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory innervation to the anterior wall of the external auditory canal (EAC). Understanding the nerve supply is essential for diagnosing and managing ear pain.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 4.

choices.text: Topical antibiotic drops with a corticosteroid

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of right ear pain, itching, and hearing loss. He reports swimming in a lake over the weekend. On examination, the external auditory canal (EAC) is erythematous, edematous, and there is scant purulent discharge. The tympanic membrane is not clearly visible due to swelling. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical antibiotic drops with a corticosteroid

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with diffuse otitis externa, commonly referred to as "swimmer's ear", which is often associated with a history of water exposure. The initial treatment typically involves topical antibiotic drops to address the bacterial infection and a corticosteroid to reduce inflammation and edema. This combination provides symptomatic relief and helps restore the patency of the external auditory canal, improving medication delivery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral antibiotics: Incorrect because oral antibiotics are typically reserved for more severe cases of otitis externa, such as when there is evidence of systemic infection or if the topical treatment fails. This patient presents with localized symptoms without systemic involvement, making topical therapy the most appropriate choice.

 

Option C. Tympanostomy tube placement: Incorrect because tympanostomy tubes are generally indicated for recurrent acute otitis media or chronic middle ear effusion, not for external ear infections like otitis externa.

 

Option D. Systemic antifungal therapy: Incorrect because fungal otitis externa (otomycosis) is characterized by itching and debris (often black or white), and is more common in humid or tropical climates. This patient’s history of swimming and purulent discharge is more suggestive of a bacterial infection, making antifungal therapy inappropriate here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial treatment for diffuse otitis externa, especially following water exposure, involves topical antibiotic drops combined with corticosteroids to treat the infection and reduce inflammation in the ear canal.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent ear itching, discomfort, and decreased hearing in his right ear. He denies any significant past medical history. On examination, the external auditory canal (EAC) is noted to be filled with blackish debris. The tympanic membrane is not clearly visible due to the debris. Otoscopic examination reveals no signs of inflammation or bacterial infection. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus Niger

 

The patient’s symptoms and findings, particularly the blackish debris in the external auditory canal (EAC), are characteristic of otomycosis caused by Aspergillus Niger. Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear, which typically presents with itching, discomfort, and decreased hearing. Aspergillus niger is known to produce black or dark-colored debris, which aligns with the findings in this patient.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa: Incorrect because Pseudomonas Aeruginosa is a common cause of bacterial otitis externa, and its infections usually present with diffuse erythema, pain, and purulent discharge. It does not typically produce blackish debris.

 

Option C. Candida Albicans: Incorrect because Candida Albicans can cause otomycosis, but it typically produces white or creamy debris, rather than the blackish debris seen in this case. Additionally, Candida infections are more likely in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus Aureus: because Staphylococcus Aureus causes bacterial otitis externa and is usually associated with purulent discharge. It does not produce the blackish debris characteristic of fungal infections like otomycosis caused by Aspergillus Niger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus Niger is a common fungal pathogen responsible for otomycosis, presenting with blackish debris in the external auditory canal and symptoms such as ear itching, discomfort, and decreased hearing.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

choices.text: CT scan of the temporal bone
MRI of the head and neck

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with severe right ear pain, discharge, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal (EAC). He was treated for otitis externa two weeks ago, but his symptoms have worsened. The physician is concerned about the possibility of malignant otitis externa extending into the skull base. Which imaging modality is most appropriate to assess the extent of his infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gallium 67 scan

 

Gallium 67 scan is particularly useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of malignant otitis externa. It is taken up by monocytes and reticulo-endothelial cells, indicating soft tissue infection. This scan can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor both the progression of the disease and the patient’s response to treatment. It is more specific than other imaging techniques for detecting the extent of soft tissue involvement in malignant otitis externa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan of the temporal bone: Although a CT scan provides excellent detail of the bony anatomy and can help identify bone erosion, it may not be as sensitive as the Gallium 67 scan in assessing early bone involvement and soft tissue infection in malignant otitis externa.

 

Option B. MRI of the head and neck: MRI offers great soft tissue contrast, which can be useful in assessing the extent of soft tissue infection, but it is less specific than a Gallium 67 scan for identifying infection in malignant otitis externa.

 

Option D. Plain radiography of the skull: Plain radiography is neither sensitive nor specific enough for diagnosing malignant otitis externa. It is not typically used to assess the extent of infection or skull base involvement in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gallium 67 scan is a highly sensitive imaging modality that helps detect and monitor the extent of infection in malignant otitis externa, especially in diabetic or immunocompromised patients.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

choices.text: To evaluate the extent of bone involvement
To assess the function of the Eustachian tube
To determine the presence of middle ear effusion

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with poorly controlled diabetes presents with symptoms suggestive of malignant otitis externa. The physician considers further imaging to assess the extent of the disease. What is the primary role of a Technetium-99m scan in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To evaluate the extent of bone involvement

 

The Technetium-99m scan is primarily used in cases of malignant otitis externa to evaluate the extent of bone involvement. This scan is highly sensitive for detecting osteomyelitis, a serious complication of malignant otitis externa that can involve the temporal bone and skull base. It helps clinicians determine the severity of the infection and the involvement of the bony structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To identify the causative organism: The Technetium-99m scan does not help in identifying the causative organism. This is done through microbiological cultures and sensitivity testing of ear discharge or tissue samples.

 

Option C. To assess Eustachian tube function: Eustachian tube function is not assessed using a Technetium-99m scan. This scan is specifically designed to evaluate bone metabolism, not the function of the Eustachian tube. Other tests like tympanometry or nasal endoscopy are used to assess Eustachian tube function.

 

Option D. To detect middle ear effusion: The presence of middle ear effusion is typically detected using an otoscopic examination, tympanometry, or sometimes MRI. The Technetium-99m scan is not used for detecting middle ear effusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of malignant otitis externa, the Technetium-99m scan is used to evaluate bone involvement and detect osteomyelitis, which is a severe complication affecting the temporal bone and skull base.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with otorrhea. Otoscopic examination reveals granulation tissue on the tympanic membrane without any vesicles or blisters. Which condition does this presentation most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myringitis Granulosa

 

Option A: 

 

Myringitis Granulosa is characterized by the presence of granulation tissue on the tympanic membrane. Squamous layer is lost and replaced by granulations. Most common cause is iatrogenic trauma. It often presents with painless otorrhea. Topical antibiotics, antifungals, steroids, antiseptics can be given. Debulking of granulations or surgical excision with grafting may be required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Acute Otitis Externa, also known as swimmer's ear, involves inflammation of the external auditory canal, often presenting with ear pain, itching, and otorrhea. While the tympanic membrane may appear reddened or swollen, granulation tissue is not a typical finding in acute otitis externa.

 

 

Option C: Bullous Myringitis is characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane, often accompanied by severe ear pain. The description of granulation tissue without vesicles or blisters does not align with bullous myringitis.

 

 

Option D: Tympanic membrane perforation is associated with hearing loss, and sometimes otorrhea. The presence of granulation tissue on the tympanic membrane is not a typical feature of a simple perforation but can be a secondary finding in chronic ear diseases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringitis Granulosa as a condition characterized by the presence of granulation tissue on the tympanic membrane, typically associated with chronic inflammatory processes of the middle ear.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg55

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent otitis media during childhood. Otoscopic examination reveals white, chalky plaques on the tympanic membrane. Which condition is most consistent with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tympanosclerosis

 

Option A: 

 

Tympanosclerosis is characterized by the presence of white, chalky plaques on the tympanic membrane and sometimes within the middle ear. These plaques are deposits of calcium and other minerals, typically resulting from chronic inflammation, such as repeated episodes of otitis media. Tympanosclerosis can lead to stiffness of the tympanic membrane and sometimes conductive hearing loss if it involves the ossicles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Acute otitis media typically presents with a red, bulging tympanic membrane, often with signs of middle ear effusion. White, chalky plaques are not a feature of acute otitis media.

 

 

Option C: Bullous myringitis is characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane and is associated with severe ear pain. It does not present with white, chalky plaques.

 

 

Option D: Tympanic membrane perforation is associated with a visible hole or tear in the tympanic membrane, often accompanied by a history of acute pain, hearing loss, or otorrhea. While perforations can lead to scarring, they do not typically present as white, chalky plaques.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tympanosclerosis is characterized by the presence of white, chalky plaques on the tympanic membrane, often resulting from chronic inflammation such as repeated episodes of otitis media.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg56

questions.text: During an otoscopic examination, a medical student observes the tympanic membrane (TM) of a patient. The attending physician asks the student to identify the landmark that appears as a triangular, light-reflecting area on the TM. Which part of the tympanic membrane does this describe?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The cone of light

 

Option C:

 

The cone of light is a triangular, light-reflecting area on the TM seen during otoscopic examination. It is caused by light from the otoscope reflecting off the surface of the TM, typically seen radiating anteriorly and downward (right side) from the umbo in the right ear and anteriorly and downward (left side) in the left ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The pars flaccida is a small, slack, superior section of the TM, located above the lateral process of the malleus. It is not typically associated with light reflection.

 

 

 

Option B. The umbo is the central point of the TM where the tip of the malleus attaches. It is the most inward part of the TM, but it is not specifically known for light reflection.

 

Option D. The pars tensa comprises the majority of the TM and is a tightly stretched portion below the lateral process of the malleus. While it is the main part of the TM, it is not specifically described as the light-reflecting area.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cone of light is the light-reflecting area seen on the tympanic membrane during otoscopic examination, which helps in orienting the examiner to the TM's anatomy.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg2

questions.text: A medical student is learning about the anatomy of the tympanic membrane (TM). The attending physician asks the student to identify the part of the TM that is prone to atelectasis and cholesteatoma formation. Which part of the tympanic membrane is being described?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The pars flaccida

 

Option A.

 

The pars flaccida, also known as Shrapnell's membrane, is the small, slack, superior section of the tympanic membrane, located above the lateral process of the malleus. It is more susceptible to atelectasis (collapse) and cholesteatoma formation due to its relatively weak structure compared to the rest of the TM.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The pars tensa comprises the majority of the tympanic membrane and is a tightly stretched portion below the lateral process of the malleus.
